Argument 24
Description:
Representative Gutierrez of Illinois, arguing in Congress on July 11, 1996, replying to Republicans arguing in favor of the "Defense of Marriage Act", a bill stipulating that 'marriage' be defined as being between a man and a woman only, excluding homosexual marriages: "I now realize that my friends on the other side of the aisle are painfully out of touch with the idea of federal non-interference when they talk about how important it is for the federal government not to interfere in the lives of our people. I understand that they are naively jesting - teasing us - when they stress the importance of taking power out of Washington and giving it to local officials. And now I know that their most sorrowful illusion is that old line about family values - all that talk about encouraging people to care about and be committed to each other."

Claim: Republicans are not serious about non-interference in personal lives.
